description: Partly from Middle English visiter, visitere, equivalent to visit +‎ -er; and partly from Middle English visitour, from Anglo-Norman visitour, from Old French visetëor.

entries.meaning: Someone who visits someone else; someone staying as a guest.
Someone who pays a visit to a specific place or event; a sightseer or tourist.
(sports, usually in the plural) Someone, or a team, that is playing away from home.
A person authorized to visit an institution to see that it is being managed properly.
(ufology) An extraterrestrial being on Earth for any reason.
examples: 5: Of course there is always the remote (I hope) possibility that instant panic will prompt us to send a hailstorm of nuclear warheads out upon the visitor.

entries.meaning: An object which lands or passes by Earth or its orbit.
examples: Within a few months, another small meteoric mass has been added to the list of those extra-terrestrial bodies which have fallen within the limits of Tennessee. This recent visitor is a stone, weighing, when first obtained, three pounds.

entries.meaning: (Britain) A head or overseer of an institution such as a college (in which case, equivalent to the university's chancellor) or cathedral or hospital, who resolves disputes, gives ceremonial speeches, etc.
(software engineering) The object in the visitor pattern that performs an operation on the elements of a structure one by one.
